
Water Level Prediction and Anomaly Detection Report
===================================================

# Introduction


This report presents an analysis of water levels in California's Central Valley using ensemble methods for prediction and anomaly detection.
# Data Description


The analysis uses data from 16 CDEC stations, including YDR, TIS, SUT, SJP, SJN, SJF, SBS, RVB, NIC, LIS, KNL, GRL, FRE, FPT, DLT, BTC. Data was preprocessed, resampled to daily frequency, and missing values were imputed.
# Model Performance


Model performance metrics:

Random Forest - MSE: 0.1353, R2: 0.7964

Gradient Boosting - MSE: 0.2233, R2: 0.6638

Ensemble - MSE: 0.1526, R2: 0.7704
# Feature Importance


Top 10 important features:

|    | feature     |   importance |
|---:|:------------|-------------:|
|  3 | SJN_value   |    0.246045  |
|  2 | SJP_value   |    0.152826  |
| 12 | FPT_value   |    0.135985  |
| 10 | GRL_value   |    0.0899846 |
| 11 | FRE_value   |    0.0566931 |
| 13 | DLT_value   |    0.047637  |
|  5 | SBS_value   |    0.0415154 |
|  1 | SUT_value   |    0.0411967 |
| 14 | BTC_value   |    0.0395721 |
| 16 | day_of_year |    0.0383488 |

# Conclusion


This analysis provides insights into water level patterns and anomalies in California's Central Valley. The ensemble model shows good predictive performance, and the anomaly detection highlights unusual water level events.
